Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating molecular connections between internal and external cues that affect seedling development
Award.AbstractNarration:
A key question in regards to improving crop productivity is how plants integrate both external signals, such as light, and internal signals, such as cues from hormones, to alter growth and development. Previous work on the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana identified several DNA-binding proteins which play similar roles in suppressing seedling elongation in response to light. Additional evidence indicates that these proteins may also interact with internal plant hormone signaling pathways. Based on these two pieces of information, it seems likely that these genes serve as molecular integration points between external light signals and internal hormone pathways that influence seedling development. This hypothesis will be tested in collaboration with Dr. Keiko Sugimoto at the RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science in Yokohama, Japan. RIKEN is renowned in the field of plant hormone research, and Dr. Sugimoto and other researchers at the institute possess specialized, cutting-edge technology and expertise which will allow two unique but complementary approaches to be used to investigate this question.

The AT-HOOK MOTIF NUCLEAR LOCALIZED (AHL) gene family, specific to and yet ubiquitous in plants, modulates hypocotyl growth in light-grown Arabidopsis seedlings. This research will investigate if the AHLs serve as a genetic integration point between light signaling and phytohormone pathways in the control of hypocotyl growth, by using two different biochemical techniques. The first specific aim will test if AHLs bind directly to DNA sequences associated with plant hormone signaling pathways, using chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-SEQ). In specific aim two, mass spectrometry will be used to evaluate if AHL genes influence the endogenous levels of various plant hormones. Specifically, hormone profiles will be generated from the seedlings of various AHL mutants and compared. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As sessile organisms, plants rely heavily on perceiving and adjusting their growth in response to external stimuli, such as light, for survival. Seedlings rely heavily on light perception to change their developmental program when they reach the soil surface, at which point it becomes advantageous for the plant to slow down elongation and begin to divert energy stored in the seed to synthesizing machinery necessary for performing photosynthesis. However, in addition to external signals, internal signals, such as those transmitted through plant hormones, also play critical roles in regulating plant development, including at the seedling stage. Previous research in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana revealed that members of a group of DNA-binding proteins, called the AT-HOOK MOTIF NUCLEAR-LOCALIZED (AHL) proteins, are important for modulating seedling elongation in response to light. In this project, we began to investigate if AHL proteins alter the development of light-grown Arabidopsis seedlings by acting on one or more hormone signaling pathways in the plant.

 

Since the AHLs are thought to act as master regulators that turn on and/or turn off the expression of numerous genes near their DNA-binding sites within the plant, the main focus of this project was to perform a procedure known as Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with one of the AHL proteins. The ChIP procedure enables the isolation of segments of DNA specifically bound by a protein of interest. Subsequent analysis of such isolated DNA can give insight into which genes a protein functioning as a master regulator of gene expression is controlling. Since the ChIP procedure is a long and highly specialized technique which can be difficult to perform correctly, the principal investigator learned how to perform this procedure in Dr. Keiko Sugimoto’s laboratory at the RIKEN Center for Sustainable Resource Science in Yokohama, Japan. Using the ChIP technique in Arabidopsis seedlings, we were able to isolate AHL-bound segments of DNA which contained genes associated with plant hormone signaling pathways. This suggests that AHLs may modulate light-influenced seedling elongation by acting on these associated hormone signaling pathways. Further, after initially learning the ChIP procedure at RIKEN, the principal investigator has begun to perform ChIP here at Washington State University, and is also teaching others how to perform the procedure.

 

In addition to learning and performing the ChIP procedure to test if AHLs bind to DNA associated with hormone signaling pathways, we also tested if AHL proteins impact the levels of any plant hormones. This was accomplished, in collaboration with Dr. Hitoshi Sakakibara at RIKEN, by directly measuring the levels of several different types of plant hormones in seedlings bearing mutations in the AHL proteins. Dr. Sakakibara’s lab is one of the few labs in the world that possesses both the equipment and expertise necessary to perform this procedure. In this portion of the project, we found that most of the AHLs tested did not cause changes in the levels of the hormones measured. This suggests that the AHLs likely do not influence the development of light-grown seedlings by directly impacting the synthesis or degradation of the plant hormones which were measured in this experiment. These results, combined with the results obtained from ChIP, suggest that the AHLs may influence seedling development in light by acting on hormones which could not be measured and/or by acting on other genes which help transmit signals relayed by hormones yet do not directly impact synthesis or degradation of the hormones themselves.
